title-group.article-title: Control for a class of four-dimensional chaotic systems with random-varying parameters and noise disturbance

abstract.p: This paper investigates the control of a class of four-dimensional chaotic systems with system parameters varying randomly under the condition of noise. Based on the sliding mode control method, the controller is designed to eliminate the chaotic behavior of a system and realize its stabilization. Numerical simulations are presented to demonstrate the validity of the proposed method. The approach proposed in this paper is simple and easy to implement and also provides reference for chaos control in relevant systems.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Chaos control with the aim of stabilizing the unstable periodic orbits or points of a chaotic system has received a great deal of interest in the last two decades, and has been applied to physics, biological engineering, chemical engineering, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, information engineering, hydraulic engineering, etc. (Schiff et al., 1994; Lu and Chen, 2005; Hua et al., 2005; Wu et al., 2008; Zhao et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2010; Chen et al., 2011a; Sprott, 2011; Sun et al., 2011; Wang et al., 2011; Yu et al., 2011). Since Ott et al. proposed a novel method for chaos control in the 1990s, many new methods for chaos control have been proposed in recent years, such as the backstepping control method (Njah 2010; Sahab et al., 2010; Li and Hu, 2011), the feedback control method (Cai et al., 2002; Ren and Liu 2006; Bashkirtseva and Ryashko, 2011), the adaptive control method (Hua et al., 2004; Ataei and Haghighatdar, 2011), the Ott Grelogi Yorke (OGY) method (De Paula and Savi, 2009; Chen 2011a), the control Lyapunov function (CLF) method (Rahmani et al., 2009; Mahmoud Gamal and Ahmed, 2011), fuzzy control (Lin and Lee, 2011; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2011) etc. One of the best methods is sliding mode control, and some good contributions have been reported, for example Chen et al. (2011) chattering sliding mode controller and the sliding mode control method is suitable for a new hyperchaotic system (Xiang and Huangpu, 2010); Lin et al. (2011) deal with chaos synchronization between two different uncertain fractional order chaotic systems based on adaptive fuzzy sliding mode control. Although some contributions on chaos control for a class of nonlinear systems have been proposed (Yin et al., 2010; Chen et al., 2011b, 2012; Li and Hu, 2011; Yoshimura, 2011), which has more theoretical significance. On the other hand, in most practical systems, the control inputs are frequently subject to nonlinearity due to physical limitations. Therefore, it is essential to take into consideration the impacts of input nonlinearity, the external disturbance and random-varying system parameters when analyzing and implementing a control strategy for the practical chaotic systems.

Consequently, this paper’s aim is to focus on the control of a class of four-dimensional (4D) chaotic systems with the system parameters varying randomly under the condition of noise disturbance using the sliding mode method. It is worth noting that the control aim considered in this paper can be achieved with only one single control input. Furthermore, the single controller is proposed in this paper regardless of the system’s noise disturbance and varying parameters, which is of great significance in reducing the cost and complexity for controller implementation. Lastly, with physical limits considered, the control scheme will be more instructional for practical systems.

This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 gives the general form model, Section 3 presents the design of sliding mode control, while in Section 4 illustrated examples are given to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control method. In Section 5 we summarize this work.

sec.title: 2. General form description
sec.p: A class of 4D systems is considered as (1){x·=f(x,y,z,w) y·=x·g(x,y,z,w)-ay z·=x·h(x,y,z,w)-bz w·=x·p(x,y,z,w)-cw where x, y, z and w are state variables and a, b, c are non-negative constants. The four functions (f(·), g(·), h(·) and p(·)) are regarded as smooth functions which belong to R4→R space.

Taking consideration of random-varying parameters and noise disturbance, the 4D system (1) can be controlled with only one controller as follows: (2){x·=f(x,y,z,w)+Δf(x,y,z,w)+φ(u(t)) y·=x·g(x,y,z,w)-a[1+d1sin(t)]y z·=x·h(x,y,z,w)-b[1+d2sin(t)]z w·=x·p(x,y,z,w)-c[1+d3sin(t)]w where Δf(x,y,z,w) is the uncertain term and considered to be bounded, i.e. |Δf(x,y,z,w)|≤δ where δ is positive constant, and di∈(0,1) while u(t) is the control input and φ(u(t)) is a continuous nonlinear function, which is designed to satisfy the following fact: (3)λ2u2(t)≥u(t)φ(u(t))≥λ1u2(t) where λ1 and λ2 are nonzero positive constants.
The control goal is to design a sliding controller and stabilize the system for any given initial conditions under the condition of system uncertainties.

sec.title: 3. Sliding mode controller design
sec.p: To realize the achievement of the control goal via sliding mode control, two basic steps for the control design are needed as follows: the first step is to construct an appropriate switching surface such that the sliding motion on the manifold can stabilize the system as expected, with any initial states and unavoidable external noise; the second step is to ensure the existence of the sliding mode S = 0.
First of all, an adaptive switching surface is defined as (4)S(t)=x(t)+ϕ(t) where ϕ(t) is an adaptive function given by (5)ϕ·=y·g(x,y,z,w)+z·h(x,y,z,w) +w·p(x,y,z,w)+rx,r>0
When the system operates in sliding mode, it satisfies the following equations: (6)S(t)=x(t)+ϕ(t)=0 and (7)S·(t)=x·(t)+ϕ·(t)=0
Therefore, (8)x·(t)=-ϕ·(t)=-y·g(x,y,z,w)-z·h(x,y,z,w) -w·p(x,y,z,w)-rx

From equation (8) the sliding mode dynamics can be obtained as follows: (9){x·=-y·g(x,y,z,w)-z·h(x,y,z,w) -w·p(x,y,z,w)-rx y·=x·g(x,y,z,w)-a[1+d1sin(t)]y z·=x·h(x,y,z,w)-b[1+d2sin(t)]z w·=x·p(x,y,z,w)-c[1+d3sin(t)]w

In the following, the Lyapunov stability theory is used to analyze the stability of the sliding mode dynamics (9). The Lyapunov function is selected as v(t)=0.5(x2+y2+z2+w2), which leads to: v·=xx·+yy·+zz·+ww·=x[-y·g(x,y,z,w) -z·h(x,y,z,w)-w·p(x,y,z,w)-rx] +y{x·g(x,y,z,w)-a[1+d1sin(t)]y} +z{x·h(x,y,z,w)-b[1+d2sin(t)]z} +w{x·p(x,y,z,w)-c[1+d3sin(t)]z}=-rx2-a[1+d1sin(t)]y2-b[1+d2sin(t)]z2 -c[1+d3sin(t)]w2≤0
According to Lyapunov stability theory, it appears that the sliding motion on the sliding manifold is stable and ensures limt→∞ ‖[x,y,z,w]‖=0 where ‖.‖ is the Euclidean norm of a vector.

The next step is to design a control scheme to drive the system trajectories onto the sliding mode S = 0. The equivalent control law is designed as: (10)u(t)=-ωη·sat(S/h),ω>1λ1 where η=|f(x,y,z,w)+y·g(x,y,z,w) +z·h(x,y,z,w)+w·p(x,y,z,w)+rx|+k , in which, k>δ and (11)sat(S/h)={sgn(S),|S|>hS/h,|S|≤h where h is a positive constant. Good approximation requires the use of small h. Theorem
As to the system given in equation (2), the controller (10) can make the trajectories of the system converge to the sliding surface S = 0 in a finite time. Proof
The Lyapunov function of the system is constructed as V=0.5S2, and from equations (2) and (4), its first derivative with respect to time is (12)V·=SS·=S[f(x,y,z,w)+y·g(x,y,z,w)+z·h(x,y,z,w)+w·p(x,y,z,w)+rx+Δf(x,y,z,w)+φ(u(t))]≤|S||f(x,y,z,w)+yg(x,y,z,w)+zh(x,y,z,w)+wp(x,y,z,w)+rx|+|S|δ+Sφ(u(t))=η|S|+Sφ(u(t))
Furthermore, using equation (3), we have (13)λ2ω2η2[sat(S)]2≥-ωη[sat(S)]φ(u(t))≥λ1ω2η2[sat(S)]2

When |S|>h and S2(t)≥0, we have (14)λ2ω2η2S2[sat(S)]2≥-ωηS2[sat(S)]φ(u(t)) ≥λ1ω2η2S2[sat(S)]2⇒λ2ω2η2S2[sgn(S)]2≥-ωηS2[sgn(S)]φ(u(t)) ≥λ1ω2η2S2[sgn(S)]2⇒λ2ω2η2|S|2≥-ωηS|S|φ(u(t))≥λ1ω2η2|S|2⇒-λ2ωη|S|≤Sφ(u(t))≤-λ1ωη|S|
Substitute equation (14) into (12), the following is obtained: (15)V·=SS·≤η|S|(1-λ1ω)

Since ω>1λ1 has been given in equation (10), it can be concluded that the reaching condition SS·≤0 will be satisfied. We obtain |S| > h, V· < 0, which implies that there exists a limit time T where |S| ≤ h, ∀t > T . Thus the proof is achieved completely. Remark 1
It is easy to check that the system can be controlled by the linear input controller proposed in this paper if only ω>1. Remark 2
It is easy to check that a three-dimensional system, such as Liu system, Lorenz system and Chen system, etc., can be controlled by the control method proposed in this paper.

sec.title: 4. Numerical simulation results
sec.p: In this section, examples are presented to verify the effectiveness of the control strategy proposed in this paper and the simulation results are modeled in MATLAB software using a fourth-order Runge-Kutta method with a fixed step size of 0.01.

The four coupled nonlinear Lorenz–Stenflo (LS) system (Liu and Yang, 2010) is described: (16){x·=-α(x-y)+γw y·=x(r-z)-y z·=xy-βz w·=-x-aw where x, y, z and w are state variables and a, β, γ and r are non-negative constants. With the parameters α = 1.0, β = 0.7, γ = 1.5 and r = 26.0, the LS system exhibits a chaotic attractor, as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Chaotic phase orbits of the Lorenz–Stenflo system. (a) x-y phase orbits; (b) x-z phase orbits; (c) x-w phase orbits; (d) x-y-z phase orbits.
Consider the system uncertainties and the control input, the LS system can be rewritten as (17){x·=-a(x-y)+γw+Δf(x,y,z,w)+φ(u(t)) y·=x(r-z)-[1+d1sin(t)]y z·=xy-β[1+d2sin(t)]z w·=-x-a[1+d3sin(t)]w

In order to stabilize the system, an adaptive surface and a proper control input are chosen as: (18)S(t)=x(t)+ϕ(t) (19)ϕ·(t)=y(r-z)+zy-w+px (20)η=|(r-a)x+(a+r)y+(γ-1)w|+k (21)u(t)=-ωη[sat(S(t))] (22)φ(u(t))=[0.5+0.4sin(u(t))](u(t))

Without loss of generality, in the simulation we choose the initial conditions of the system [0.5, 0.8, 0.2, 0.4], the uncertainty term Δf(x,y,z,w)=0.5sin(πx)sin(2πy)sin(3πz)sin(4πw) where |Δf(x,y,z,w)|≤δ<1 and d1 = 0.3, d2 = 0.5, d3 = 0.7. And then k = 1, λ1 = 0.1, λ2 = 0.9, h = 0.01 and p = 1, ω = 11.

The system parameters a = 1, β = 0.7, γ = 1.5 and r = 26.0 are specified for simulation. Figure 2 shows the time domain charts of state variables and sliding surface with system parameters fixed when the control is activated at t = 1. Figure 3 shows the time domain orbits of state variables and sliding surface with system parameters varying when the control is applied at t = 1. Figure 2.
The time domain orbits of state variables and sliding surface with system parameters fixed when the control is applied at t = 1. (a) x-t orbits; (b) y-t orbits; (c) z-t orbits; (d) w-t orbits; (e) s-t orbits.
Figure 3.
The time domain orbits of state variables and sliding surface with system parameters varying when the control is applied at t = 1. (a) x-t orbits; (b) y-t orbits; (c) z-t orbits; (d) w-t orbits; (e) s-t orbits.
Obviously, the simulation results presented confirm the validity of the proposed control.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: We have investigated the control of a class of 4D chaotic systems with system parameters varying under the condition of noise disturbance via the sliding mode method. We have given illustrated examples and numerical simulation results are employed to verify the efffectiveness of the control scheme. In practical systems, with noise disturbance and varying system parameters considered, the control scheme proposed in this paper is of significant importance due to its simple and effective execution and good robustness.
